summary: Honestly, Yoda’s line at the end of AOTC, the one about victory, is just pure genius. The old man just saw what his old padawan...
body:
Honestly, Yoda’s line at the end of AOTC, the one about victory, is just pure genius. The old man just saw what his old padawan had become and this was the most subtle yet most powerful way to show how much that affected the Grandmaster of the Jedi Order.

Even though they won, it is not victory because a) so many Jedi got killed, and b) his old padawan had committed himself to a Sith Lord.

Even though they won, it is not victory because a) so many Jedi got killed, and b) his old padawan had committed himself to a Sith Lord.

Even though they won, it is not victory because a) so many Jedi got killed, and b) his old padawan had committed himself to a Sith Lord.

blog.name: abandoned-as-mustard
blog.title: I Am Become Trash
blog.description: 20, Aussie, Multifandomer with a cat. Cares about fiction as much as I post: way too much. I switch between TV, movies, books, occasionally random memes and aesthetics. Basically, whatever I feel like. Enjoy the ride.

summary: you antis must feel real big calling people names like 6 year olds huh
title: you antis must feel real big calling people names like 6 year olds huh
body:
You people don’t care about the full story of something, you don’t even read the whole post before you reblog and gang up on someone. 

That says a lot more about you than me. 

And it’s just a fandom, guys. When someone “””misinterprets””” something, KINDLY tell them so without being an asshole and they’ll understand. Getting on your high horse doesn’t help anyone. 

It’s hilarious, you block someone to get the last word, then everyone who sees your response goes and harasses the blocked person, sticking their fingers in their ears when said blocked person explains the situation. 

You’re a bunch of vipers. But you can’t scare me away.

And it’s just a fandom, guys. When someone “””misinterprets””” something, KINDLY tell them so without being an asshole and they’ll understand. Getting on your high horse doesn’t help anyone. 

It’s hilarious, you block someone to get the last word, then everyone who sees your response goes and harasses the blocked person, sticking their fingers in their ears when said blocked person explains the situation. 

You’re a bunch of vipers. But you can’t scare me away.

You people don’t care about the full story of something, you don’t even read the whole post before you reblog and gang up on someone. 

That says a lot more about you than me. 

And it’s just a fandom, guys. When someone “””misinterprets””” something, KINDLY tell them so without being an asshole and they’ll understand. Getting on your high horse doesn’t help anyone. 

It’s hilarious, you block someone to get the last word, then everyone who sees your response goes and harasses the blocked person, sticking their fingers in their ears when said blocked person explains the situation. 

You’re a bunch of vipers. But you can’t scare me away.

You people don’t care about the full story of something, you don’t even read the whole post before you reblog and gang up on someone. 

That says a lot more about you than me. 

And it’s just a fandom, guys. When someone “””misinterprets””” something, KINDLY tell them so without being an asshole and they’ll understand. Getting on your high horse doesn’t help anyone. 

It’s hilarious, you block someone to get the last word, then everyone who sees your response goes and harasses the blocked person, sticking their fingers in their ears when said blocked person explains the situation.

tags: glad to have him as my dad
my dad is the king of nerds
summary: Star Wars and talking to my dad about toxic fandom
body:
Star Wars and talking to my dad about toxic fandom

I know, this topic is a bit different for me - but I wanted to talk about it. I’ve largely stayed away from discussing it, but I feel with the growing hate for actors and the new movies, I wanted to bring it up.

As I’m sure my long time followers know, my dad got me into Star Wars. The Phantom Menace trailer was released around the day I was born - that’s 1999. I’ve grown up with the new generation of Star Wars fans (the ones that love Hayden and the cast) and listened to the older generation bitch about the new content - prequels, Abrams movies, CN Clone Wars, etc.

But never once have I heard my father talk shit about the actors, and I asked him why.

He said to me this: “It’s not their fault they were given shitty scripts and told to act. People don’t seem to remember that the original Star Wars scripts aren’t that great either, and it was largely improvised by the actors as they went along. When it came out, Star Wars was new and fresh - everyone wanted it to stay that way. They didn’t want to see Anakin go from a whiny kid to Darth Vader. They wanted the original cast, and that wasn’t going to happen.”

True, he wasn’t a fan of Jar-Jar, the Trade Federation plotline, or how they chose to portray Anakin at times. But you know what? He never hated on the actors, and he feels awful what the new actors - Rose, Daisy, Adam, John, etc. - are going through.

As a result of the prequels and the sequels, he’s a huge fan of Ewen, Natalie, Adam, Daisy, and Kiera Knightly. I cannot tell you how many times he’s dragged me to the theater because one of them has a new movie. He’s always been happy that Natalie and Kiera could be a role model to me growing up - ‘cause I didn’t have alot of female role models in my family.

Yes, we were both a little disappointed when the new movies were announced - because it was 30+ years of lore being wiped about. But we kept all of our EU stuff, and went to support the new movies anyway. It’s not the best of stories, true, but that’s just my opinion. I still want to see how this story ends.

(I cannot tell you how much he liked the fact Rey wasn’t a Skywalker or a Kenobi. He thought it was fantastic, and brilliantly set up any new movies Lucas Films wish to do in the future.)

I bet you’re wondering about the Clone Wars then, and his thoughts on that? Well, that came out when I was about nine or ten - and he thought it was decent. The movie he loved, but the first season kind of turned him away from it. I didn’t watch it again until I was about sixteen, just when it ended.

I remember sitting on the couch, a barf bucket on the floor, and a heated blanket around me. I had gone through the first two seasons in like three days (I was really sick okay) - and you want to know what arc he came in on?

The Mortis arc.

He sat down and watched it with me - and loved it. Not as much as me, but enough to be a fan of Rex and Ahsoka. He thinks the voice actors are phenomenal. He actually thought it was Hayden voicing Anakin, I kid you not.

He wasn’t a big fan of Rebels, saying it just felt a bit off to him. But he still appreciates the effort put into it, and watched the episode when Ahsoka came back, and when Obi-Wan faced Maul for the final time.

Before I finish, I’ll say this one last thing.

His favorite Star Wars movie?

A New Hope?

His second favorite Star Wars movie?

Solo.

He’s been a fan since the beginning, has been a beta tester for the games for 20+ years, and still finds it in his heart to appreciate every aspect of Star Wars.

And if that’s not the definition of a true fan, I don’t know what is.

reblog.comment:
Star Wars and talking to my dad about toxic fandom

I know, this topic is a bit different for me - but I wanted to talk about it. I’ve largely stayed away from discussing it, but I feel with the growing hate for actors and the new movies, I wanted to bring it up.

As I’m sure my long time followers know, my dad got me into Star Wars. The Phantom Menace trailer was released around the day I was born - that’s 1999. I’ve grown up with the new generation of Star Wars fans (the ones that love Hayden and the cast) and listened to the older generation bitch about the new content - prequels, Abrams movies, CN Clone Wars, etc.

But never once have I heard my father talk shit about the actors, and I asked him why.

He said to me this: “It’s not their fault they were given shitty scripts and told to act. People don’t seem to remember that the original Star Wars scripts aren’t that great either, and it was largely improvised by the actors as they went along. When it came out, Star Wars was new and fresh - everyone wanted it to stay that way. They didn’t want to see Anakin go from a whiny kid to Darth Vader. They wanted the original cast, and that wasn’t going to happen.”

True, he wasn’t a fan of Jar-Jar, the Trade Federation plotline, or how they chose to portray Anakin at times. But you know what? He never hated on the actors, and he feels awful what the new actors - Rose, Daisy, Adam, John, etc. - are going through.

As a result of the prequels and the sequels, he’s a huge fan of Ewen, Natalie, Adam, Daisy, and Kiera Knightly. I cannot tell you how many times he’s dragged me to the theater because one of them has a new movie. He’s always been happy that Natalie and Kiera could be a role model to me growing up - ‘cause I didn’t have alot of female role models in my family.

Yes, we were both a little disappointed when the new movies were announced - because it was 30+ years of lore being wiped about. But we kept all of our EU stuff, and went to support the new movies anyway. It’s not the best of stories, true, but that’s just my opinion. I still want to see how this story ends.

(I cannot tell you how much he liked the fact Rey wasn’t a Skywalker or a Kenobi. He thought it was fantastic, and brilliantly set up any new movies Lucas Films wish to do in the future.)

I bet you’re wondering about the Clone Wars then, and his thoughts on that? Well, that came out when I was about nine or ten - and he thought it was decent. The movie he loved, but the first season kind of turned him away from it. I didn’t watch it again until I was about sixteen, just when it ended.

I remember sitting on the couch, a barf bucket on the floor, and a heated blanket around me. I had gone through the first two seasons in like three days (I was really sick okay) - and you want to know what arc he came in on?

The Mortis arc.

He sat down and watched it with me - and loved it. Not as much as me, but enough to be a fan of Rex and Ahsoka. He thinks the voice actors are phenomenal. He actually thought it was Hayden voicing Anakin, I kid you not.

He wasn’t a big fan of Rebels, saying it just felt a bit off to him. But he still appreciates the effort put into it, and watched the episode when Ahsoka came back, and when Obi-Wan faced Maul for the final time.

Before I finish, I’ll say this one last thing.

His favorite Star Wars movie?

A New Hope?

His second favorite Star Wars movie?

Solo.

He’s been a fan since the beginning, has been a beta tester for the games for 20+ years, and still finds it in his heart to appreciate every aspect of Star Wars.

And if that’s not the definition of a true fan, I don’t know what is.
